awd_titl_txt: LSAMP BD: Florida International University FGLSAMP
awd_abstract_narration:
The Florida Georgia Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (FGLSAMP) is establishing a 2018-2020 Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) site at Florida International University (FIU) to increase the number of LSAMP doctoral degree awardees.  The program will train the BD fellows to a doctoral degree and encourage them to transition into a career in academia to serve as a role model for other students. FIU, has a proven record of recruiting, retaining and graduating minority students in STEM. The FGLSAMP-FIU site addresses the National Challenge of "increasing the participation and success of underrepresented minorities in S&E contributes and to the health of the nation by expanding the S&E talent pool, enhancing innovation, and improving the nation's global economic leadership."

FIU proposes a multi-faceted, student-centered initiative that will leverage the past successes of FGLSAMP in fostering high academic achievement amongst underrepresented students in STEM, and the "best practices" of fifteen prior FGLSAMP BD cohorts at FIU, FSU, UF, and USF that have supported over 200 minority graduate students. The objectives of the proposed program are: 1) recruit and place LSAMP undergraduates into STEM PhD programs at FIU, 2) ensure successful dissertation research  and training for all BD fellows; 3) provide structured professional development activities to develop a strong learning community,  support network of "like-minded" minority scholars, and promote their successful retention in a STEM doctoral program; 4) educate fellows for the global STEM workforce through extended national lab and international research experiences, 5) provide guided mentoring for the success of BD fellows, and 6) engage BD fellows in K-12 outreach, teaching, and near-peer mentoring of LSAMP undergraduates that will enable them to inspire the next generation of minority scientists and engineers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Florida-Georgia Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation’s Bridge to the Doctorate Program (BD) at Florida International University (FIU) was designed to increase the number of LSAMP graduates who obtain STEM doctoral degrees, and successfully transition them into post-graduate careers within the industry, government, and academia. FIU's FGLSAMP BD student research and training opportunities built upon existing strategic investments (NIH MBRS RISE, NIH MARC U STAR, Ronald McNair Scholars, NSF FGLSAMP BD,NSF FGLSAMP, NSF CREST, NSF PIRE, NSF NERC-ASSIST, etc.), and the University's long history of commitment to minority undergraduate and graduate STEM education.

FIU’s third cohort (2018-2020) accomplished the following objectives:

Recruited and placed 12 LSAMP students into STEM PhD programs at FIU: The cohort was comprised of students from historically underrepresented populations and came from numerous alliances (Florida-Georgia, Tennessee, Garden State, and Puerto Rico). Three students are at the candidacy stage and seven are at the pre-doctoral state. One student has already graduated with a PhD.

Ensured state-of-the-art thesis/ dissertation research training with FIU STEM Faculty: Upon entry into the program students successfully chose a research mentor and project. The students were also advised on how to build healthy mentor relationships.

Provided structured professional development activities that resulted in a cohesive and supportive “like-minded” community of minority students and their successful retention in a STEM doctoral program: Through professional development workshops, the students honed their communication and writing skills. Programming continued to be offered during the COVID-19 pandemic to maintain the sense of community and workshops on science communication, conference networking and conflict resolution were offered. The BD program had a retention rate of 92%, with one student leaving the University and BD program after the first year.

Educated students for the global STEM workforce by facilitating both national lab and international research experiences: Students attended the LSAMP-BNL Scientific Computing Graduate Workshop offered by Brookhaven National Laboratory. Students also developed their professional networks by participating in internships both in industry and government agencies.

Engaged Fellows in K-12 outreach and near-peer mentoring of LSAMP undergraduates that enabled them to inspire the next generation of minority scientists and engineers: Students were encouraged to conduct outreach activities in the local community. For example, students presented their research projects, experiences, and journey as graduate students to REU students at FIU and at local high schools to expose younger students to scientific research.

Five students began the program in the 2018-2019 AY and seven students began in the 2019-2020 AY. Upon completion of the BD Program:

  • One student received the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship
  • Two students received competitive Fellowships (NASA, FEF McKnight)
  • Four students received a Research Assistantship
  • Two students received a Teaching Assistantship
  • One student is self-funded
  • One student graduated with a PhD and is working in industry
  • One student left the university and BD program

Last Modified: 11/07/2021
Modified by: Nezih Pala
